Award.AwardTitle: Examining the Factors that Affect the Implementation and Sustainability of Exploring Computer Science (ECS) in School Districts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research and Evaluation Group at CEMSE (Center for Elementary Mathematics and Science Education) at the University of Chicago will support the CS 10K effort by contributing to a necessary knowledgebase for CS 10K success through the following project goals: (1) Informing CS 10K leaders and other CS educators about the supports and barriers to wide scale high school CS education implementation and providing strategies for addressing them; (2) Providing tools for measuring CS program implementation and the supports and barriers that affect implementation; and (3) Creating products from research findings and recommendations about implementing and growing CS education. This project builds on CEMSE's previous NSF work rigorously studying implementation of educational innovations (new practices and programs) and the factors that affect innovation implementation and sustainability.

The research team will accomplish the project goals by examining implementation of the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) program and identifying the supports for, and barriers to implementation in several large school districts. Specifically, the project will rigorously study ECS implementation in Chicago, Los Angeles, and Washington, DC with a focus on the factors that currently affect ECS use, with particular attention to how and why these factors vary in the different contexts. The study will focus three research questions: (1) What is the status of ECS implementation in each site?; ( 2) What supports and barriers contribute to or inhibit the implementation and endurance of ECS?; and (3) To what extent do these supports and barriers differ by location and over time? The team will employ a mixed-methods research design using data collected through teacher and student questionnaires; ECS developer, school district personnel, school leader, and teacher interviews; and student focus groups.

Researchers will work collaboratively with CS 10K project leaders, CS education advisors, and school and district practitioners to produce findings and share timely and useful information with involved stakeholders through publication, presentations, on-line reports, webinars, and in-person discussions. The study will highlight the challenges to systemic efforts to increase accessibility, quality and quantity of high school CS education and offer recommendations to meet those challenges, ultimately helping the K-12 CS community bring needed programs into schools, and support lasting, systemic change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Computer science (CS) educators are engaging in unprecedented efforts to expand opportunities in K-12 CS education. With this comes a need to develop shared language and valid measures to communicate with one another about what is happening in different settings where CS is being offered, the key supports and barriers that influence implementation of programs and student engagement in CS, and what is needed to grow and sustain K-12 CS education. To that end, the purpose of the BASICS study was to support implementation and expansion efforts. The CS education field faces many of the same challenges that preceding curricular efforts have faced. For example, the public and policy makers will ask about the effectiveness of particular materials; school leaders and teachers will need to understand the necessary supports and barriers to bringing CS to classrooms at scale; and developers will need to understand how to ensure that their instructional resource and professional development experiences are feasible and accessible to an ever-widening teacher and student audience.

The study undertaken by Outlier Research & Evaluation sought to help the field address these challenges by: 1) informing policy, school, and stakeholder leaders about the supports and barriers to wide-scale high school CS education implementation and strategies for addressing them; 2) providing tools for measuring CS program implementation and the supports and barriers that affect implementation; and 3) creating products from research findings that included resources and recommendations for implementing and growing CS education. Over the course of the project, we have collected qualitative and quantitative data from several school districts across the country and analyzed that data to generate findings to meet these goals. 

More specifically, the study developed instruments that answered the following questions: (1) What is the status of ECS (Exploring Computer Science) implementation? And (2) What key supports and barriers affect ECS implementation? Although the study sought to inform the field at large about high school CS in general, and the supports and barriers that may affect that implementation, for practical reasons, the work focused on one particular introductory CS program. This was not, in any way, an evaluation of ECS. Rather, given that the study sought to create tools for measuring CS program implementation in schools, this study focused on this widely-used CS program as an example, while giving attention to applicability of study products and findings to settings not using ECS.

Intellectual Merit: The project stems from our previous NSF studies that rigorously studied implementation of educational innovations (new practices and programs) and the factors that contribute to and inhibit innovation implementation and sustainability. This earlier work provided an empirical foundation for measuring and analyzing curriculum program implementation and the supports and barriers to implementation. BASICS survey instruments provide CS education researchers and evaluators with valid and reliable measures for implementation (teacher and student report of how the ECS materials are used in practice, and assessment of the contextual factors that influence teacher us of the materials, and student engagement in the class), enabling more systematic review and assessment of what is, and what is not working, possible reasons why, and where critical supports are needed and barriers removed. Over the course of development and refinement, the instruments were administered three times to students and teachers in classes using the ECS curriculum.

The team created additional instruments for measuring the contextual factors that influence on instructional materials use and student engagement. As with the survey instruments, these qualitative instruments were informed by conceptual frameworks developed through earlier work at Outlier and review of relevant literature. This second set of instruments includes a teacher interview protocol and a student focus group protocol. Influences measured are categorized generally in to three main types: individual influences, school influences, and environmental influences,

Broader Impacts: A deeper understanding of the supports and barriers to ECS and other introductory CS efforts will help the K12 CS community move toward a solution for bringing needed programs into schools, and ultimately support lasting, systemic change. One project outcome for the community is a website to make our study resources accessible to both practitioners and researchers. It serves as a hub for research-informed resources relevant to CS teachers, and school and district leaders (“Findings About CS Education in Schools”) as well as project-developed tools for researchers (“Instruments to Measure CS Implementation”). Teacher, school, and district leaders can use these resources to consider what is needed to introduce CS into a district or school, and to gather data about what is happening in practice in classrooms (and what needs adjustment). This study worked to provide these types of useful and practical tools and information to the current and growing portfolio of CS education efforts at a time when there is an opportunity to carry CS education into the mainstream of the education system.
